Created an attachment (id=45332)
console log with osgi debug options on

console with debug options on.
Same problem on a real nokia communicator.

For the system bundle (org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.0.200606222211) BundleDescription.isResolved() method returns false. In BaseStorage.checkSystemState(). 
I have played with the state bits on the debugger to make it start once. After this initial start isResolved() starts to return true for subsequent starts. but I was not able to use the workbench. No UI was visible.

It looks like the OSGi Execution Environment is not being set correctly.  This will cause the system bundle not to resolve.

What class library are you using?  CDC 1.0/Foundation 1.0?  What is the value of the system property java.specification.name?
Try setting the following system properties in your config.ini

microedition.configuration=CDC-1.0
microedition.profiles=Foundation-1.0

This should causes the framework to load the java profile CDC-1.0_Foundation-1.0.profile from the org.eclipse.osgi system bundle.  This is used to set the org.osgi.framework.executionenvironment system property to 
 OSGi/Minimum-1.0,
 OSGi/Minimum-1.1,
 CDC-1.0/Foundation-1.0
I have modified config.ini and this did the trick to start eWorkbench.

(In reply to comment #5)
> I have modified config.ini and this did the trick to start eWorkbench.
> 

I did it too, eWorkbench is starting but I don't have the list of applications. It is written "No item in the list" both on the emulator and on the phone. 
Is the demo working with you ?

Created an attachment (id=47771)
swt plugin with corrected manifest
There is also an issue with the swt plugin. It is not exporting the packages. I have attached a corrected version of that. It should start working if you replace it with this copy.

Regarding the changed manifest for the org.eclipse.ercp.swt plugin...
For Win32 and WM2003 we have fragments to this host plugin that export the SWT packages. A host plugin does not control what a fragment exports, so it's not really appropriate that we make this change on the Win side. If you provide eSWT libs on the classpath, you are really just faking out other plugins that you provide SWT packages in a bundle.
What should probably be done is to make S80 eSWT a fragment just like the Win fragments and then eSWT would be a replaceable bundle in the framwork, just like every other part of eRCP.  Alternately, you could add SWT packages to your Execution Environment profile. This might be complicated though. Second best might be to provide a dummy fragment that exports eSWT packages in the manifest, but they will still come from the classpath.

(In reply to comment #8)
> There is also an issue with the swt plugin. It is not exporting the packages. I
> have attached a corrected version of that. It should start working if you
> replace it with this copy.
>
